title: Lipoma vs. Liposarcoma
diagnosis_topic: Evaluation of a subcutaneous mass with consideration of malignancy
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman presents with a soft, mobile mass on her upper arm that she noticed two years ago. It has grown slowly and is now about 5 cm in diameter. She denies pain, weight loss, or systemic symptoms. How would you proceed with evaluation and management?

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident performs physical exam of the mass
dynamic_flow.reply: Mass is soft, rubbery, mobile under the skin, nontender; overlying skin appears normal.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about history of growth or symptoms
dynamic_flow.reply: Growth has been gradual; patient denies pain, fever, or weight loss.
Differential includes benign lipoma, liposarcoma, epidermoid cyst, and other soft tissue tumors.
Ultrasound shows a homogeneous, hypoechoic, well-circumscribed lesion consistent with lipoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds to MRI (lesions >5 cm or deep)
dynamic_flow.reply: MRI demonstrates a well-encapsulated superficial mass without invasion into muscle or surrounding structures.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident raises concern for malignancy
dynamic_flow.reply: Malignant features would include size >10 cm, rapid growth, firmness, fixation, pain, or infiltration; biopsy indicated if suspicious.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident recommends excision without biopsy
dynamic_flow.reply: Local excision can be offered for symptomatic relief or cosmetic reasons; pathology required.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays biopsy or excision in suspicious case
dynamic_flow.reply: Mass continues to enlarge and becomes firmer, raising concern for liposarcoma.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident discusses management of liposarcoma
dynamic_flow.reply: Treatment would require wide excision with negative margins, referral to surgical oncology, and possible multidisciplinary care.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for multiple lipomas
dynamic_flow.reply: No additional lesions found; no family history of multiple lipomatosis.
Instruct patient to keep incision clean and dry; advise on monitoring for recurrence.
Patient is counseled to report rapid growth, firmness, pain, or other new concerning features.

critical_decision_points: Clinical evaluation of subcutaneous masses, considering size, depth, and growth characteristics.
Appropriate use of imaging and biopsy for suspicious lesions.
Patient counseling regarding recurrence and warning signs of malignancy.

resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated solid diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the features distinguishing lipoma from liposarcoma. Your management decisions regarding imaging and excision were well justified. Communication with the patient was clear and empathetic.Areas for Improvement: Earlier escalation to biopsy when malignant features arise would strengthen clinical judgment. At times, your counseling did not fully address the potential implications of a malignant diagnosis. Ensure you consistently provide comprehensive follow-up instructions.Suggested Reading Topics: - Evaluation and management of soft tissue masses (SCORE) - Differentiating benign from malignant soft tissue tumors (ACS/ASE Core Curriculum) - Principles of biopsy and surgical excision of soft tissue tumors
